40873353.review:
I got this game in a humble bundle for pennies pretty much and after around 5 hours I think I've got enough to write a review about it. Those 5 hours consisted of about 2 arcade matches figuring out the controls and then hopping into story mode. I just picked the first character which was Sol Badguy. I then spent a little bit fighting 4 enemies and not really minding the challenge. This is where it all goes downhill. I have no idea who was in charge of creating the bosses, but they should be drug out into the street and shot. See, all bosses have gimicks. Once boss for instance just regenerates health, another boss' gimick is that he can take out 3/4ths of your health bar in 1 combo, can get even more powered up and also regenerates his health, meaing that his gimick is that he's a near unbeatable piece of shit. I've played a few fighting games in my day, but none have made me more frustrated than this. I wouldn't recommend this game to worst enemy, I'm pretty sure I could have beaten the entirety of the first Dark Souls game in the time it took me just to beat the last 2 enemies of Sol's "story." I put that in quotes because it has the bare minimum of what a story should have.

In short, fuck this game. Go right on past it and never look back. Just pick up some other fighting that doesn't make you want to staple your nutsack to the ceiling.

Edit: Came here to edit my review as I'd calmed down and then tried the game again. I looked in the options menu and saw that the game was set to normal difficulty, so I dropped it down to beginner and tried the same route again. Man, it was so much easier. The two bosses that gave me the most trouble, I-no and Order Sol were much more mangagable. My fighting game background isn't the best (came from Street Fighter 2, 4, Skullgirls, those kinds of games) and this apparently has a much higher skill ceiling. If you're like me and this is your first Guilty Gear game, don't be afraid to drop the difficulty down. It is fairly easy to learn a few combos that link together nice, but I don't think the game has a tutorial mode that I think would have been nice. I still have problems with the story though. Mostly because even after playing through it twice (Sol's story), I have no idea what is really going on. I guess it assumes so other knowledge on my part of a previous game, but the story is bonkers. I believe the online is mostly dead as well because most people probably moved to the new Guilty Gear game. In short, I know longer think it's a piece of shit, but there are other more beginner friendly games out there that I think would be easier to get into.

Guilty Gear is a fun little series with an interesting cast and a rocking soundtrack. The problem is the control scheme and keybinding. The game assumes you will have a pair playing on the same computer and doesn't give you the option to just not have that on by default. Player 1 can't force control bindings for some reason, instead you have to rebind everything in player 2's control scheme, which I cannot do because the button I need to assign keys with does not exist. The default controls thereof are awkward to use. Even using a controller, the game forces me to use the analog stick rather than the directional pad, which does not make the controls less awkward, particularly for dashing.

While the issue is only borderline game-breaking in my case because I'm not playing on the appropriate OS, the arbitrarily awkward keybinding is still a major issue with the game that creates a rather negative experience for me. I feel these flaws should be fixed before I can recommend it, unless you get a deal to rival a Jellyfish plundering.

So this is another one of those pervy weeb fighting games. They can be super entertaining, or super painful depending on your sense of humor. 40107107.review:
this game serves as a gameplay upgrade to Guilty gear X2 #reload and a story sequel to the said game, it's basicly GGX2 but with more characters, an additional online mode without the need of a mod, and most importantly : a support for the modern resolutions .
sadly and much like most of Arc sys's fighting games : you'll have a pain in the ass to figure out how to edit the control keys properly. the mission mode is now even easier than how it should be , the missions got reduced to a total of 30 instead of 100 and an info bubble is shown to indicate how you should win in every mission to make it easy for everyone to read the info chart that the mode gives you for every mission . 
the story is now even more explained and polished as this game explains the unexplained in the GGX2 events ( most of it but not everything sadly) . the gallery mode features beautiful  illustrations that are unlocked in a way that encourages you to replay the game more than twice .
the online mode uses a p2p connectivity and it's netcode is decent, the controls now do feel even smoother than GGX2's.
the price is fine, 15$ for a game containing more than enough of what anyone would want for a fighting game + the soundtrack given for free by the devs, once again! , but it gets  a minus one point for lacking a tutorial, because none would get how everything works unless you do some extern researches.
9/10 not the best but one of the best .

EDIT : the language support, according to the store page, shows that it supports many languages in the interface level, i expected the menus and stuff to be modified, but after switching to the french language only some message bubbles got changed such as the saving message bubble, the menus, the commands list and literally anything that you'd expect didn't get a modification .

39444480.review:
ARC System Works wächst über Capcom und SNK hinnaus
Wir schreiben das Jahr 1998 nach Christus. Das ganze 2D-Beat'm Up Genre wird von Capcom und SNK beherrscht. Das Ganze Genre? Nein. Denn in diesem Jahr trat auf Sonys Playstation mit der Guilty Gear Reihe ein weiterer Mitstreiter auf den Plan, mit dem sich der bis dato unbekannte Entwickler ARC System Works neben Street Fighter, King of Fighters und Co seinen Platz in dem Genre sicherte. Während das tolle Ambiente zu seinem erscheinen als eine Mischung aus Samurai Warriors und Dalkstalkers beschrieben wurde (Video Games Oktober 1998), konnte auch das Gameplay vollends überzeugen. Dazu kamen bildschirmfüllenden Special Moves, die bei einem derart flüssigem Gameplay aufgrund des geringen Ramspeichers der Playstation derzeit eigentlich nur auf dem Sega Saturn als realisierbar galten. Und der Erfolg der Guilty Gear Reihe hält bis heute an: Während sich Streetfighter in dieser Generation als totaler Reinfall herausstellte, und auch King of Fighters nicht mehr DER große 2d-Prügler ist, der er noch um die Jahrtausendwende war, werden die Prügler von Arc System Works, zu denen neben Guilty Gear auch die BlazBlue-Reihe zählt, mehr denn je zu der besseren Alternative. Mit den vielen Modi bietet diese Reihe auch gerade für Einzelspieler mehr als die großen Konkurrenzspiele. Außerdem kann man Guilty Gear, ganz ohne Gamepad, im Versus Modus gegeneinander an einer Tastatur spielen. Das sollte zwar bei PC-Spielen irgendwie Standart sein, wir wissen aber alle, dass es das nicht ist. 
Mir gefällt das ältere GUILTY GEAR XX ACCENT CORE PLUS R, welches 2012 als Arcade erschienen ist sogar noch besser als das neuere Guilty Gear Xrd -SIGN- von 2014, das es nicht ganz so effektüberladen ist und sich mit der leicht Pixeligen Grafik auf Playstation 3-Niveau den Charme der alten 2d-Prügler bewahrt hat, der neueren Vertretern des Genres wie den neuen Street-Fighter und King of Fighters-Spielen verloren gegangen ist.

37665949.review:
Guilty Gear Accent Core Plus is another one of the Guilty Gear/Blaz Blue series. There are so many that you wonder why their business model is about rehashing the same thing over and over again. One would assume that they would add 2-4 new heroes per release per annum. At that rate, over a 10-year period, you would have 20-40 new heroes. 

Guilty Gear Accent Core Plus gives you 25 characters to choose from with 2 repeats. 
a. Sol Badguy and Order Sol 
b. Ky Kiske and Robo-Ky

Even Guilty Gear Xrd REV 2 has only 26 characters. It's not exactly a lot. You would be expecting a buildup of even more characters. Hopefully, it will hit the 40 unique character mark.

Conclusion, this is an old game since there is an XrD series now. Try it when it's on sale.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Concept
I like the concept. Simple and cool.

2. Enhanced Modes
I like characters being able to have a simple normal attack mode and a super-powered up mode. E.g. Sol Badguy and his ultimate.

3. Simpler than Blazblue
Actions are not as complex so a larger audience can pick up the moves.

4. Status Effects
Poison: Zato-1's stage
Heavy: Can't jump at all. Testament does this to Ky Kiske with earth binding magic. 
(Heavy could also be Mei's status effect ie. tying an Anchor to your leg). It would be better as a special skill.
Cursed : Can't Block at all. Sol Badguy stage

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Artwork Lower Grade?
Certain parts don't look that cool. One example is the scene where Sol Bad Guy stands over Justice.

2. Keyboard Can't Work Well
The bare minimum is a D-pad. Best is joypad. The game is not designed to appeal to all systems. Unlike games like Warframe which seem to run on any platform. The combos are just to difficult to pull off.

3. No Proper Notation
Since this is a direct console port, there is no proper notation of what button corresponds to what. E.g. X, Y means Punch or Kick? Check the controller settings to get what I mean.

4. The Design of Justice
A bit lame. It's a dragon humanoid mecha with a tail but it's too bland. It needs to be slightly improved.

5. Command List Explainations
Could it all be changed to arrows? I know what the Z symbol means but it's not clear enough.

6. A.B.A's Blood Pack
It's crucial to know how to transform. I had to guess which one was the transform action.

7. Unicorn Head, Raven
The ugly shit.

8. I-No final boss, Anji Mito
I was expecting some super power. Nothing. Just a normal Anji Mito fight.

9. Chip Zanuff's Kick Ultimate
So many hits, so little damage. Thematically, you are expecting something painful after getting hit by a blade after so many hits. I understand that it might be for game balance but it's quite lame.

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. Character Design
I kind of like GG's characters a lot but you can see a very strong similarity to Darkstalker. Both in artistry and mechanics. E.g. Testament plays like Jedah from Darkstalker while the rest are like the following in the list. But of course, I liked Darkstalkers.

"Morrigan vs I-NO
Demitri vs Sol Badguy
Donovan vs Ky Kiske
Felicia vs Jam
Lei-Lei vs Dizzy
Anakaris vs Faust
Sasquatch vs Potemkin
Zabel vs Eddie
Bulleta vs Zappa
Jedah vs Testament
Dee vs Order Sol "

2. Never Getting the Action You Want
Semi-circle back-forward is always confused with uppercut. It's mostly me but I feel that this is one problem of fighting games. The actions and combos just can't be done right by the majority of people.


[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. RPG-Fighting Hybrid
I think one super-impactful idea that I can think off the bat is a RFH. This is basically a Guilty Gear Characters side-scroller. It would be a co-op side-scroller. You can look at Guardian Heroes for what I mean. There is no leveling system, just player skill. However, the focus will be PvE. You will find different monsters, mobs and challenges. Finally, there will be a boss fight. You can choose to play good guy or bad guy. You will fight NPCs like the Holy Knights, Unique Gear Bosses, Big Giant bosses that will need high jumping to hit. Like Apocalyse and Onslaught in the Marvel vs Capcom series. You will get to explore the world of Guilty Gear. Enter shops to buy healing, pick up AI buddies, etc.

The idea is to appeal to a large audience. For those who like the skilled fighting, play PvP multiplayer or PvAI. For those less skilled players, play RPG style with friends in co-op mode. Actually, the more I type, the more I want Darkstalkers 4 to have it. GG lacks the expandability and continuation of Darkstalkers. I want to fight cool giant bosses with friends and pull out flashy ultimates. There maybe some issues like "touch ultimates" since they work on a normal sized model but not on a giant sized boss.

There's a lot of work to be done but I think a developer like ARC should have the resources to plan it out. There's Guilty Gear Judgement but I think you need a whole package deal. Basically, you have a RPG + Fighting Game all in one-set. Newbies play co-op vs AI RPG, pros play fighting PvP. Like Metal Slug levels, keep moving right.

2. In-Game Tutorials of Combos / Tips
I don't know what the combos for each hero are. All I see are the actions. It would probably be great to record a few short replays to show the different combos. E.g. 8-hit combo for Sol Bad Guy. I'm not talking about the L1 record button.

3. Air Zone
I think high-jumping into the air like Marvel vs Capcom opens up a whole new avenue of gameplay and powers for each hero. Currently, the zone is limited to a short rectangle. You can input high air dash, downward strikes/slam, climbing ladder combos, 

4. 3v3 Continuous Tag Teams
This is an old idea but I like the Marvel vs Capcom/KOF "pick-3-heroes"  combo. It opens up more replayability and removes the staleness of playing just 1 character over and over again. You also need to be able to swap heroes mid-battle, not the KOF style of having 1 hero die, move onto the next match and wait for the opposing hero to die. That's very time-wasting. In-game, that's called Team 3v3, very slow and few opportunities to combo.

5. More Status Effects Moves
Faust can Poison, Sol Badguy can Burn. Rather than all moves doing just damage, how about a lingering status effect for each Hero? E.g. 

Weaken : 0 Defence
Slow : Move slowed and jump reduced
Peace : Can't Attack at all

6. Chun Li/E. Honda/Blanka Heroes
Where's the hero that gets to mash the same button over and over again? You need an easy hero for newbies.

7. Destructible Levels
Halfway through the match, the floor gives way and collapses and you get air battle. Or Match 1 ends, floor gives way to underground arena.

8. Crowd Effects
All the background are kind of boring. If you win, the AI should cheer, get pissed off, fireworks should shoot up or an explosion should happen. If either side wins with an ultimate, a special effect should occur.

9. Valentine instead of A.B.A
While Valentine is from GG2 : Overture, her design is better than A.B.A's key. Also, no 3D space fights please. The 2D is pretty good already.

10. Bad Ending, Good Ending, Hidden Ending
You know how many games have these 3 endings? It's time for GG to have that too for each hero. A bad ending if you choose the easy route, a good ending if you choose the hard route and a hidden ending if you choose the insane route.

11. Super-Powered Up Version of each Hero
Like I-No in the Arcade mode or Slayer when Faust fights him (this is a bad example as all he does is heal a lot). Every hero should have some crazy boss mode with skills that are not normally usable.

12. Interesting Future Playable Characters
Crow Kurasabe and Johnny's Master Uncho. You can always resurrect them with evil cloning technology.

13. Robo-Ky and Order Sol
Instead of the obvious reference to Sol and Ky, perhaps Robo-Ky can turn into a robot all on his own? Think of a name like Rob-O. Robo-Ky's horny nature seems to fit with the name, Rob-O. Story-wise, he just upgrades himself after the self-destruct sequence.

36073000.review:
Not very beginner friendly (although overall much easier than #Reload) and unless you're willing to look in the forums or join a Discord server, you won't find any games online.

That said, it's still an amazing fighting game. GG has always been about flashy combos, extremely diverse gameplay amongst characters and Heavy Metal aesthetics. Accent Core decided to take all that up to eleven and remains the craziest, most robust Guilty Gear there is.

While many of the "AC" additions were actually introduced in GGXX Slash, AC decided to break the norms by essentially making everyone mini boss characters. Everyone can easily deal high damage, character moves have unique properties that assist their playstyle, new hit states (slide, bounce etc) and the new Force Breaks are there for when your character's gimick just isn't enough. For instance, Sol gets his big damage from Sidewinder loops, but if you can't bother with his Clean Hit mechanic, you can use FB Sidewinder for a guaranteed Clean Hit for only 25% Tension!

Then there are the EX characters and old GG modes and if you thought GG wasn't crazy enough, boy have I got news for you... I really miss the EX characters in Xrd, they added so much more depth to the game, even if most of them were broken for one reason or another. Still, it was just really damn fun messing around with them. GG modes are a fun addition too, but I certainly didn't miss the GG1 style Instant Kills... 

Finally, the rest of the modes include a Story and a Mission mode with much less bullshit than their #R counterparts and a Survival Mode that's actually fun. Oh and M.O.M. if you like that, I guess. Extras include old mid 2000s fanart, some of which still looks great.

As a bonus, if you don't like +R's changes, you can always switch back to the old AC+ version. Relive exciting momments such as Slide Head combos, non-FB Sidewinder loops and playing as the broken versions of Kliff and Justice!

Despite the short time I have put into this game right now Steam, due in most part to my work, I do wanna say that I am making this review/opinion from my experience of this game series while I was in college back in the early 2000s.
What I can say from this short time is that, this is very slick, this is probably even more slick than the game GG X / X2 Reloaded that I played for hundreds of hours and that impression came from just a couple of full playthroughs. (If this title interests you by the by, those older other tie in names to the series mentioned are definitely worth a recommendation too. They are just as good as this, only slightly older versions and a very tiny bit outdated in places)

To the pros of fighting games and this series, you might like this.. This is a definitely testing game for fast reflexes, combos and strategy on the fly, the only downside is unless you may have some biases with the art style in the game, which in contrast opinion, is possibly the strongest suit right next to the gameplay and controls.
I can't speak much more in depth than what I know from tournaments and the tricks of being very good skill-wise in this game, as I am not really a hardened veteran / pro of this game, so for a more detailed opinion, this might not be it.

For casuals, it might be a bit hard to recommend as the game is fairly difficult, but that I don't think should be a bar to set for casual players, as it is not impossible to learn as you go, That's after all how a lot of us learned the basic jist of the game and got better at it, we just played it and even if we lost, we all kept trying harder and better the next time. :)
The most important way to decide if you want the game in my opinion, that depends on whether you really are convinced that this is a game you want to play and if you're confused by what that means, I'll use myself as the example of how I got into this game. Back when I used to play the other games a lot, I wasn't into fighing games, it actually was more the style and entire presentation of the game, the characters and all the other sweet things found here, such as tricky moves to pull off, Overdrive moves, etc., all those things in combination made me hyped enough to pick it up and play the hell out of it, just having fun however stupidly or good I was playing. Even now I'm not That good at this game, but god damn if I do not enjoy playing it..

In short, it doesn't matter how good you are with fighting games, if you have the time to play it and you just want to play it based on what you've seen for yourself about the game, I dont think a skill ceiling will be enough to stop you from getting into this game.. all in all, this game offers superb controls and gameplay, but more important, all its characters have style.. The game is just a superb jewel and should be at least checked out, to get your impression on whether or not you want it.

33977416.review:
This is possibly the most solid fighting game ever. I can't imagine how good Xrd is if it is better than this game. Heavy Metal Rock was something I didn't like when I first encountered Guilty Gear music and although it was pure rock and I hated it at first, this is really the best video game music I can think of. As for the characters, each has a lot of story behind them that you have to play or research multiple games to fully understand.

Every character in this game is really cool and over-the-top. The game was basically balanced by making characters extremely powerful, but be thankful you didn't get a version where Eddie was able to destroy anyone if in the hands of a master player. Even bottom tier characters can take tournaments as people are known to play Sol and Ky despite them being rated near the bottom of tier lists.

You will be dealing with a very complex game in Guilty Gear. Special moves aren't super easy to do and you will have a lot to be remembering. But you can basically optimize how you handle any situation through skill because of things like Faultless Defense (take no damage and space away any attack), Full Roman Cancel (stop attacking mid-move to perform another move) and Gold Burst (gives a huge boost in tension if it hits or is blocked).

Accent Core Plus R is not only the most balanced version of the game, but it also gives characters the most attacks they have ever had in the XX series.

The game is really fast paced and not really beginner/casual friendly, so I don't quite recommend you buy this game until you get adjusted to 2D fighters and how to learn them, but the game is very rewarding to play due to the fact that you can continuously improve your performance with the various mechanics and moves and large cast of characters.

This game is basically a must play, but I guess on the other hand, if you don't try this, at least try Xrd, which has much more advanced training for new players and a more flexible gameplay style.

33304028.review:
I could not recommend more.
GGXX AC +R is a freaking amazing fighting game, and by far my favorite game in my favorite franchise in fighting games.
To be honest, I didn't play any Guilty Gear for years since I last played GGXX on GBA (or was it GGX?), but the presence of the franchise on Steam made me buy it to revive my love (and nostalgia) for this game, and what I discovered was like a brand new experience, even though I was familiar with it years ago. It's the same game, it looks and feels like it, but it also feels as it has grown, in a positive way, you know?

So, let's go to the review, starting with the story. 

-Well, story wise, I'm still finishing story mode of most of the characters, but I'm kinda lost since I don't remember anything of previous games, so I've read about the story before this one, and it's pretty good and interesting. Kinda confusing at first glance, though, but still good.

-Great art and character design, sprites in this game (the whole franchise, in fact) are amazing, and the stages (background places and all) are equally great, each having their own "feeling".

-Characters are as great as design. They all really charismatic, each in their own ways, and if you like the game and play it for a couple of hours, you'll likely remember them all. They all have their own essence and personality, which is pretty well worked through story. Other good think I think about the characters is that you can kinda "feel" their personality only by fighting against or using them, which is something every fighting game should at least try to accomplish.

-I don't know if I really have to say this, but this game has the best soundtrack I've EVER had the pleasure to hear in any fighting game, and I'm not sure if that's really true but it really feels that this franchise got famous mostly because of it's soundtrack. The voices of all characters are great, and is also one of the best dub I've heard in fighting games (Except when Jam starts screaming, that's kinda annoying since I always play this with the volume at max... But still great dub for her too)
SOUNDTRACK IS PURE DIVINE COMPOSITION MADE BY THE GODS THEMSELVES. I just thought I should remember that part. 

-There are plenty to do in the game, with various modes options and unlockable, plus the achievements makes it even better, with some being REALLY hard to accomplish, so it's all a great challenge for those looking for it.

-Which takes me to my next and final point, the gameplay. Now, Guilty Gear is not like other fighting games we know (except for those that followed his path), and it's kinda hard to explain but I can resume it in two words and one phrase: "Frenetic", "combos" and "love for the character". This last one my not make much sense if you're a stranger in the franchise, but you REALLY need to love the character you're playing. I mean, you don't have to worship them or love only them and don't give a shit about other characters in the game, but you NEED to love the character if you want to fully master him or them, For example, I love May, Jam, Ky, A.B.A and Chipp, those are my favorites and I my main/best characters, the ones I master (almost) completely, but that doesn't mean I can't play with Justice, Baiken or Millia (if that was the case I would never finish even story mode). And of course, there's some I simply can't make one combo right, like Potemkin, so I just stick to some tricks and finish his story, but would never pick him on versus mode.
Got what I'm trying to say? That complement the character's session I was talking about earlier, each having their own gameplay, so if you get this game and doesn't like one or two, try a few more of them before saying the game sucks, maybe you can find your character(s).

Also, if you play or played BlazBlue, Dead or Alive, Tekken, Street Fighter, The King of Fighters or whatsoever, be warned that your knowledge of those fighting games may not be too useful. I tried playing BlazBlue thinking the the opposite side and what happened was "ah, I play Guilty Gear and I'm pretty good at it, so this might be okooooooh shit this is different. Why are things so sloooooooow!!! WHERE IS MY COMBOS? WHY I CAN'T MAKE A COMBOOOO?! SOMEONE HELP ME PLS", so be careful.

And btw, the game is difficult as heaven (or hell), so if you like challenges, go for it. Sometimes it's so hard it gets you pissed, I actually lost count of my rage quits in this game, but it's probably between 20~50. (Really, I feel like a no-life waste in society for playing this in maniac/very hard, and also kinda masochist)

-So after all...
Guilty Gear is a REALLY frenetic fighter where the most important things are combos, knowing your character and understanding the gameplay in general, so you probably won't get anywhere smashing random buttons all the time and hoping something good happens, you really need to practice and work your way to get better in this wondeful (and pretty much forgotten on the mainstream fighting game scene) franchise. 

I'll give it a 10/10 without regret, but I know and understand that it might have some problems (not having a rage quit counter being one of them), though I don't really think things like "too difficult" can be considered a problem (right, IGN-san? c:), and I think that even with said problems, it doesn't impact on the score for me. And yes, I consider this to be the best fighting game ever made. 

Ah and btw the soundtrack is really good.
I'm serious, it's pretty good, trust me.
You should try listening to it a bit later.
For real.

my first foray into guilty gear was xx reload. that was back around 2003 i think? i was not a newcomer to the fighter scene even then, having played games like street fighter 2 and fatal fury since their inception in the early 90s, and all that came after, from tekken to soul calibur to mortal kombat and all through the king of fighters series almost religiously. but ... guilty gear was different. the pace was so much quicker, and truth be told, took me the longest time to eventually work out how to string combos properly.

as for this installment in particular: guilty gear xx accent core plus r, this is like ... super street fighter 2 turbo, or a king of fighters 2002 UM ... the definitive edition of the series; fine tuned balancing and all, this is ... a great experience for any guilty gear fan.

mind you, guilty gear is not really a game for anyone who just randomly wants to pick up a fighter. games like street fighter would be more forgiving for a newcomer, but guilty gear really requires a lot more 'commitment' from a player so to speak, as it is fairly punishing. but nothing beats the satisfaction of stringing together a nice looking combo, and you wont really get much flashier looking combos than in guilty gear.

a must-get for any fan of the series.

30451028.review: Out of the several other fighting games that I have in my Steam Library, this has to be at the very least in my top 3, if not the best I've played so far.  Even though I'm complete garbage at fighting games in general, I found myself playing this game and being driven to enhance my skill, despite it being an old game.  The roster is quite large, with varying playstyles across the board, save for two characters that are semi-clones of the two main characters, but even then, they play drastically different from their original counterparts.  There are a handful of characters that can be picked up easily and can help develop skills and fundamentals for the characters that are more difficult to learn.  However, the game's difficulty in some of it's modes can be troublesome for new players, so if you're a completionist, remember to set it to a lower level lmao.  As for local play, I personally enjoy the Team Vs. Mode, it definitely has that King Of Fighters feel to it, playing out like a crew battle, where the winning character moves on to fight the next with some of their health restored if they took any damage, and there's always the classic One-on-One Vs. Mode.  The mechanics can be quite a task to understand for newer players too, but compared to the three different Roman Cancels in Xrd to the two in ACR, for newer players, even the one less tech to know definitely means an easier learning experience.  The speed at which the game plays is intense, and it's probably the only GG title in my library that I can run, since the only other GG game I own is Xrd, and my laptop isn't the best.  However, netplay can be tempermental at times, sometimes when I try to invite someone, or even the other way around, the guest of the room will randomly be kicked, so this might be a game that you'll most definitely want to play local multiplayer with.  Even with the netplay issues, most of the time it's not an issue, since most people don't go online.  But if you have a less than stellar setup, can find yourself a friend with a Steam-supported controller, or even an arcade stick, this game will kill time for you like no one's business.

29574901.review:
Before the Xrd series came out, Guilty Gear as a fighting game franchise has gone through a long period of time as a traditional 2D fighting game, and it has built quite a reputation among the FGC community. Most GG fans can agree that the franchise peaked when the XX version came out in 2003 with an extreme commercial success, being the version that has defined the franchise for the years to come. For a long time, when you mention the name "Guilty Gear", most people are identified with the XX games that were released in the 2000s.

ArcSys has spent almost 10 years perfecting the X2 games, releasing #Reload and Accent Core, each title includes a plethora amount of expansions and spin offs. Their X2 run ends with this version, Accent Core Plus R.

It is safe to say, being the concluding version, this game has the most balanced and improved gameplay out of all the X2 versions. It is hard to be able to locate any flaws in this version. For me, the only thing that bothers me is that the stages that are unlocked by beating the Story Mode paths are not playble in the online games. And I miss the voicelines that were incorporated in the pervious X2 versions, which are removed in AC+R.

If anyone wants to experience Guilty Gear's finest, most balanced and most completed gameplay of the franchise, this is definitely the version you are looking for.

28536582.review:
[h1]My Terrible, Terrible Review of Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus R (Divided by the Power of the First Gear et al.)[/h1]
[i]Take my old terrible, terrible review of #Reload and paste the addenum: "SHUTUP! THEY'RE HERE, FUCKER! THEY'RE ALL HERE [strike]except Ultimax[/strike]!" over it. [b]I rate it: 3 daredevils / 3 ***[/b][/i]

It took a while, but slowly Arc Sys has been putting their repetoire of fighting games on Steam and it somewhat seems like each port takes notes from the last. Take that unofficial netplay patch for #Reload, make it legit and not as difficult to deal with, add a character from the black sheep of the series [spoiler](Isuka, not Overture)[/spoiler], do about two renditions worth of balancing and gameplay tweaks, add an extra mechanic or two, and that's ^Core+R for you.

As for netplay, nobody seems to play much anymore, so you'd have to hit up the online fight games community to find matches. That's not so bad, since that'd make it a bit easier to find matches with someone close to you for a hopefully better connection. RIP Ranked Mode though I guess.

The training mode has more in-depth options like setting certain character's moves to certain properties (i.e. allowing infinite coins for Johnny, setting the charge to Jam's kick specials, etc.), which is more than any other fighting game that I have [strike]I think anyway[/strike], making it simpler to experiment. The only thing it's really missing compared to fighting games released nowadays is the option to change input lag to simulate online, a trial mode to teach you some bread n butter and fancy nancy combos, and that color editor that was only in the Guilty Gear that nobody wants to play.

The single player modes are more or less the same from the previous iterations. There's a new story for all the characters. M.O.M. Mode adds Order Sol as the hidden boss (and also arcade mode), and the Survival mode added some sweet new stat mechanic that allows you to have better stats and some special buffs like a Glass Cannon sort of skill or adding elemental damage after you beat !BLACK! versions of characters (HERE COMES DAREDEVIL). It's pretty fun, son.

Not really much else to say, [spoiler]except when's Ultimax, but there's probably some form of licensing hurdle abound, so probably never.[/spoiler]

[b]~ Catch you later,
Mike Van Halen[/b]

[u]Great classic fighting game![/u]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is very basic and gets complex overtime. You start by doing simple combos like a> b> c to then proced to to do more advanced stuff. Its important to say that this game is totally combo heavy, I mean, there is little space to zoning and anti-air, like you usually do in Street Fighter.

[h1]Characters[/h1]

There is a large roster of character, each one more unique than the other. Some might be too anime-esque for you taste, but there are some with a more westernized style that you might like. But, as a whole, the game has definitely and anime feeeling.

[h1]Game Modes[/h1]

There is a variety of game modes, like Arcade, Training, Story and others, which I think is enought to compensate for the almost dead online comunity.

[u]Overal, its a pretty solid and classic game that every fan of fighting game in general should have in his/her library.[/u]

[h1]I give it 4.0/5.0[/h1]

24450385.review:
This review is split into two parts depending on your previous experiences with the Guilty Gear franchise: 1) newcomer, or 2) existing Xrd player.

[h1]PART I: NEWCOMER TO GUILTY GEAR[/h1]

The Guilty Gear franchise primarily focuses on providing fighting games that are inspired by animé, have a lot of gameplay options, are very nuanced, are very fast paced, are extremely “flashy” and “over-the-top”, have a very diverse cast of characters, and have an intricate universe for the characters and backstory.

What sets Accent Core Plus R (ACPR) apart from other Guilty Gear titles both past and present, and also other fighting games in general, is its extremely high ceiling of technically difficult gameplay; the opinion is widely held that ACPR is the most technically difficult fighting game to master. However, this does [b]not[/b] mean that the game is unapproachable to all but those able to become masters. Rather, what this means is that the game has plenty of room allowing players to grow and really develop unique play styles in general as well as character-specific. ACPR is at the pinnacle of the previous generation of games where lots of attention to detail and bombardment of information takes precedence over accessibility and simplicity.

ACPR was never really intended to attract new people to the game. It is merely the culmination of previous iterations of Guilty Gear XX with more content added, gameplay tweaks, and balance changes. As such, it wasn't considered a "new" entry in the Guilty Gear franchise. The long road to ACPR is:

XX -> XX #Reload -> XX Slash -> XX AC -> XX ACP -> XX ACPR.

The iterations span generations of consoles going all the way back to 2002 and the PlayStation 2 and Xbox era right up to 2012 and the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360.

People who desire lots of options and freedom in a fighting game will do well to pick up ACPR. However, those who want a more streamlined entry into the series and a thriving community should instead consider starting with the latest iteration in the Xrd sub-series available on Steam (currently Xrd -REVELATOR-). Those preferring the latter approach will likely not notice any technical differences between the two games until much later.

[h1]PART II: EXISTING GUILTY GEAR PLAYER[/h1]

If you are familiar with Guilty Gear titles only [i]prior[/i] to ACPR, then it suffices to say that ACPR is simply the culmination of previous iterations having more added content, gameplay tweaks, and balance changes. It faithfully preserves what is expected of a 'Guilty Gear' title.

ACPR is the pinnacle of technical difficulty in the Guilty Gear franchise. The latest Xrd sub-series, which come after ACPR, serve to make 'Guilty Gear' more accessible to a wider audience with the specific effort to attract new players while at the same time retaining the previous player base. What this means is not necessarily a “dumbing down” of ACPR, but rather to allow players to become proficient at the game at a faster rate. Ultimately, though, Xrd does have a lower technical ceiling than ACPR. Nonetheless, Xrd is still a game that requires a high degree of proficiency to master - it’s just not as high as ACPR. People who have plateued in Xrd and want to take their Guilty Gear game to the next level for personal satisfaction will thrive in ACPR.

The creator of Guilty Gear, Daisuke Ishiwatari, gave an excellent interview explaining the design choices of Xrd and how they differ from ACPR in order to make the game “milder”:

http://www.eventhubs.com/news/2014/jun/11/guilty-gear-xrd-milder-version-past-entries-creator-daisuke-ishiwatari-reveals-thinking-behind-xrds-design-decisions/

Xrd:
- Less emphasis on individual pride in being able to pull off highly technical combos;
- Now accepts buffered inputs in a number of situations; and
- Reworking of Roman Cancel (can cancel most attacks on whiff and can visually confirm more easily when comboing).

Additionally, not mentioned in the above article, is the removal from ACPR of Force Roman Cancels, Slashbacks, and Force Breaks. You can find more information on these mechanics from the following pages:

[b]Force Roman Cancels[/b]
http://www.dustloop.com/wiki/index.php/GGACR/Movement#Cancels

[b]Slashbacks[/b]
http://www.dustloop.com/wiki/index.php/GGACR/Defense#Slashback_.28SB.29

[b]Force Breaks[/b]
http://www.dustloop.com/wiki/index.php/GGACR/Controls#Force_Breaks_.28FB.29

An exhaustive explanation of ACPR can be found on Dustloop:

http://www.dustloop.com/wiki/index.php/Guilty_Gear:_Accent_Core_%2B_R

*****
Personally, ACPR is my favourite entry in the Guilty Gear series. For me it’s not so much the technical prowess it requires (I’m actually very terrible at the game and nowhere near what would be considered “proficient”), but rather the freedom it gives me to accentuate my own play style.

23909186.review:
[b]Se você estiver à procura de um jogo de luta estilo "Típico jogo de arcade de todo bom bar de esquina" e que não seja Street Fighter, The King of Fighters ou Mortal Kombat, e que seja melhor ou tão bom o quanto, Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus R [spoiler] (que nome comprido, não?) [/spoiler] é a opção perfeita para quem curte luta baseada em sprites, excelente trilha sonora, boa história, combos absurdamente altos e é claro! , meter a porrada nos amigos no multiplayer local! [/b]

Eu até então não conhecia a franquia Guilty Gear, pois a mesma não é tão conhecida aqui no Brasil, até por um acaso, jogar a sua versão de Playstation 2 (que foi a mesma que essa, só que sem o R :v ), e logo de cara ví sua qualidade apenas por ouvir a musica de abertura, que para quem curte bom Rock, Metal ou similares, já se apaixona de primeira. Esta é a versão mais atualizada do jogo Guilty Gear XX [spoiler] (isso explica o porque do nome ser tão grande assim) [/spoiler] , trazendo melhorias, novos personagens jogáveis, modo história (ao um estilo similar à visual novel [spoiler] só que sem o romance e sem nudez :v  [/spoiler]  ), modos adicionais de jogo e uma HUD mais atraente, tornando assim, muito mais interessante que suas versões anteriores.

[b] [h1] *Prós: [/h1] [/b]
[list]
 [*]Excelente qualidade gráfica de sprites e animações dos mesmos.
 [*]Excelente trilha sonora, que se encaixa muito bem com o clima do jogo.
 [*]Jogabilidade perfeita e bastante fluída.
 [*]Uma grande lista de personagens e cada um com sua característa, estilo de jogo e habilidades únicas.
 [*]Compatibilidade com outros joysticks, além do próprio controle do XBOX.
 [*]Modo história interessante (nada de muito espetacular mas não deixando de ser bom).
 [*]Suporte à multiplayer local e online.
 [*]Suporte à vários idiomas.
 [*]Porte para PC muito bem feito.
[/list]
 
[b] [h1] *Contras: [/h1] [/b]
[list]
 [*]Outros idiomas não traduz 100% do jogo (pelo menos no caso do PT-BR).
 [*]Multiplayer online não funcional, pois não consegui jogar uma vez se quer ( o qual me causou dúvida: se é devido a falta de players ou se é um erro do jogo).
 [*]Resolução de aspécto 16:9 não preenche toda a tela, assim deixando as laterais vazias ou com bordas (como ele foi um porte para PC, acredito que tenha sido culpa do jogo original ser em 4:3).
[/list]

Sem sombra de dúvidas, este foi um dos melhores jogos de luta já produzidos e um dos meus favoritos, sendo uma excelente alternativa para quem procura um jogo do gênero e quer uma experiência diferente dos demais! 

10/10

Review:
The gang's all here!  Everyone from earlier installments in  the series and some new ones are playable in this game.  Xrd -SIGN-'s missing a lot of these chraracters, and -REVELATOR-'s still going to be missing a fair amount of them as well.  If you play this game locally, you're going to have a lot of fun, but don't expect to play it online.  For one thing, the community's moved on to Xrd, now that that's finally out on Steam, and secondly, the netplay in this port is bad.  It turns the game into Street Fighter, it's just that slow.  But judging the game on its own merit, it's easily one of the best fighting games ever made.  You can't go wrong buying this.

Pros:
The graphics are the same as you remember them, but don't scale well at higher resolutions.
Best soundtrack in the series.
It's Guilty Gear at its finest.
The netcode is decent.

Cons:
Audio quality seems tinny compared to the console version.  I don't know what's up with that.

21702485.review:
A fine port of the console +R patch. I had no idea this game would come to PC and when it did I snatched it right away!

Please bear in mind this is NOT FOR BEGINNERS, especially folk new to fighting games as a whole! I am not at all new to fighting games and I very much struggle with this game, later versions of Guilty Gear made it what some consider the hardest 2D fighting game. While some may not agree that it is THE hardest no one can deny that it is one of the hardest and honestly it is the main problem I have with Guilty Gear. It's difficulty is almost needless.

Unfortunately I still have to recommend it? Why? Because as a series it is one of the best and more interestingly designed fighting games you will fine. Ishiwatari Daisuke is a brilliant game designer and composer and one of the best in the industry. There is one thing even the most casual of players can enjoy about Guilty Gear as a series and that would be it's legendary badass soundtrack. Just damn, damn, good to say the least.

IF YOU MUST HAVE A GUILTY GEAR GAME ON STEAM PLEASE PICK XRD. Seriously, Xrd is not easy either, but much nicer to newer players while this game is about nice to new players as a flaming electric chair and roughly the same even with hardened players, but it's just well made and very respectable. Character designs are really good as well and go with with their respective themes.

Overall I still prefer it's sister series Blazblue, but Guilty Gear is worth the time of any hardcore fighting game fan.

21582317.review:
Zaznaczam z góry - jeżeli multi jest Twoim priorytetem to odpuść sobie AC+ i kup Xrda lub poszukaj nieoficjalnej wersji online do Reload. Netcode jest tutaj w najlepszym wypadku średniawy. 

A tak ogólnie? Po kolei:

Plusy:
1. Różnorodność postaci, każdy powinien znaleźć coś dla siebie.
2. Dość dobry balans wspomnianych już wyżej postaci.
3. Prześwietna muzyka, energiczny j-rock. (OST znajduje się w folderze z grą, miła niespodzianka)
4. Bardzo ładna grafika, śliczne sprite'y i przyjemne dla oka (z pewnymi bardzo nielicznymi wyjątkami) areny.
5. Sporo trybów gry - Arcade, M.O.M, Survival (zarówno klasyczny jak i nowy), vs (włączając w to Team vs na styl King of Fighters), Mission i dość rozbudowany Story mode.
6. Ogrom rzeczy do odblokowania. Od ilustracji, poprzez nowe areny aż po nowe warianty postaci.
7. Dobre sterowanie, można przyjemnie grać nawet mając tylko klawiaturę.
8. Order Sol!

Minusy:
1. Multiplayer. Płynność jest w znacznej części uzależniona od odległości pomiędzy graczami, do tego występuje delay do którego ciężko się na początku przyzwyczaić. Mało jest też opcji konfiguracji.
2. Poziom trudności kilku fragmentów gry. Lubię wyzwania, ale niektóre misje czy achievementy są zwyczajnie chore. Jeżeli chcesz odblokować 100% zawartości to niezbędny będzie spory zapas leków na uspokojenie.

Niektórzy zgłaszają problemy z muzyką/dzwiękiem oraz z odpalaniem gry na Windows 10, więc miejcie to na uwadze przy zakupie. O tym drugim nie mogę się wypowiedzieć ponieważ używam 7, a co do tego pierwszego - osobiście przenigdy się z tym nie spotkałem, a mam już parę ładnych godzin gry na swoim koncie.

Lekki zawód, ale w dalszym ciągu bawię się znakomicie.

21340787.review:
In fighting games, the trend has always been that a game's released, the game isn't well-balanced or very fun to play in-depth due to the unpredictable nature of meta-game evolution and a lack of understanding of the systems that were being implemented in the original release, and so the game receives update after update, refining it and adding new characters and concepts built with the understanding gained from previous releases. The updates each do worse commercially than the last, because refined things aren't as sexy as brand new things. It's hard to sell people on a better version of a thing they already have. So eventually, the carefully polished game is pushed aside for a brand new one, full of imperfections but fresh visuals and ideas.

Those final versions of those games, however, tend to remain loved by a cult following. After all, they're the result of years and years of player feedback. Sometimes close to a decade of it. Fighting games like Super Turbo, 3rd Strike, The King of Fighters '98. They're all final love letters to their most loyal fans before their respective series ventured off into brave new directions.

Accent Core Plus R is that love letter for fans of Guilty Gear XX, and it's written so well that it's hard for newcomers not to swoon over it, too. It's a game literally ten years in the making. With the exception of newcomers Kliff and Justice (who had previously been included as bonus console characters with no consideration for balance), the characters as they're represented in Plus R are based on years and years of player feedback. When Xrd was released later, it turned back the clock on its returning characters in an attempt to simplify them and not overwhelm players. As Xrd continues to see updates, that'll change. But for now, most of the Guilty Gear characters' Plus R iterations are the most interesting and fun they've ever been.

That said, there are definitely problems with this package. Getting the game to run without heavy input delay requires some fiddling with settings, both in-game and via NVIDIA Inspector (though you could get away with only adjusting the in-game settings). Additionally, the netcode is bad, and makes playing online both a chore and, often, a much, much less pleasant experience than playing someone offline. Lobbies are limited to two players at a time, and there are no replays, either. Meaning there's no way to watch others play, and potentially learn from them.

Still, though. Plus R is the most fun fighting game I've ever played, and is fun enough for me to happily put up with those shortcomings. The game's an absolute joy, and if you've got people to play it with locally, then you absolutely have to at least try it. If all you've got is online play, I'd still encourage you to give it a chance! There are Steam and Discord groups specifically for trying to find opponents with good connections!

21049611.review:
HEAVEN OR HELL!

Uhrum... voltando:

Guilty Gear é uma série de jogos de luta da Arc System Works (a mesma que trabalha com BlazBlue) que mescla um jogo de luta, com uma estória bem elaborada, gráficos que lembram anime e personagens muito carismáticos, mas vamos ser mais expecíficos:

Eis aqui a versão definitiva do Guilty Gear XX (que vem sendo atualizada desde o #Reload, e como a ASW não tem o hábito de fazer grandes atualizações por DLC, vende em forma de jogo novo), que é a ultima das edições "XX" (já que antes dessa temos 2 Ancient Core', Slash e também dito a #Reload).

Tem uma jogabilidade extremamente amigável, graficamente bonito (talvez não para os padrões atuais, mas ainda continuo achando belo os efeitos visuais), uma trilha sonora IM-PE-CÁ-VEL (que até hoje não vi ser superada e pode talvez ser emparelhada pelas OST de BlazBlue... rock orqustral extremamente bem trabalhado) e é extremamente leve.

E diferente da outra versão lançada pela Steam também, a #Reload, essa tem um ótimo modo online funcionando e operante, tanto seja pra ranked (que não sei informar se tem gente online depois Guilty Gear Xrd - SIGN), quanto para jogar com os amigos.

Eis um jogo que caso ache em promoção (já que agora existe o Xrd, só assim para recomendá-lo), não pestaneje e LET'S ROCK!

19842115.review:
I'm going to say it. This game was a fantastic fighting game for its time. It outclassed Street Fighter IV, Mortal Kombat vs. DC, and was on par with the likes of BlazBlue and KoF 13.

However, unfortunately, the game of 26 characters and hard-to-master, yet competitive and fun gameplay, is now outdated somewhat, as Guilty Gear Xrd SIGN has come to the market for a reasonable price of $33 CAD. But, if you can't afford that game, are a GG collector, or if you want the pure nostalgia this game brings, it's for you. Also, it's a better purchase at just $17 CAD.

+PROS+
+Great storyline, it's very unique to its competitors and has a multiple choice outcome
+The sprites are fantastic, and look like they've jumped out of an anime, at a good framerate and 720p graphics, they're great to go along with the menus, stages, and life bars
+Netcode is great, if you can find somebody to play with
+Unique roster of characters, such as Sol (typical fighting game asshole, has a sword to make him cooler), Ky (police officer, except French, not stereotypical, and has a sword), Jam (a girl who works a restaraunt joint, has a build you'd cream your pants over), Chipp (American, but he's a wannae Japanese ninja, still cool), and Bridget (crossdressing nun kid who can kick your pedophilic ass with his yo-yos)

-CONS-
-The game is outdated with the release of Xrd
-A nonexistent amount of people play this game online nowadays
-Using sprites, some people say that the game is 'outclassed' for its time; I don't neccesarily agree with this since it's the way the devs wanted it to be
-Too many storylines to complete, they also overlap and it starts to get boring
-Gameplay is extremely difficult to master, if you play online with noob status, you'll most likely get sent to hell and back

In the long run, if this were earlier in 2015, I'd give it a 94/100, but since it's getting older, I'm gonna give this, albeit fantastic game, an 86/100.

19227497.review:
Antes de tudo, não se engane com meu tempo de jogo aqui na Steam, passei muitas horas jogando ele originalmente no PS2 e depois no PS3 (e ainda continuo, além dos outros jogos de luta que tenho na Steam, a maioria eu também possuo nos consoles), como sou um grande fã da série, também adquiri o jogo para o PC.
Sou um grande fã de jogos de luta, particularmente é meu estilo de jogo favorito, já joguei praticamente quase todas as diferentes séries de jogos de luta (Street Fighter, KOF, Tekken, Mortal Kombat, BlazBlue, Dead or Alive, Virtua Fighter e muitos outros e até aqueles que quase ninguém conhece, acredite) e gosto bastante da grande maioria, não tenho problema algum em jogar séries diferentes.

Na minha opinião, Guilty Gear é o melhor jogo de luta que já joguei, não desmerecendo os demais que, como eu já disse, curto a grande maioria. Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus R (melhor chamar logo só de Guilty Gear) é o jogo da série Guilty Gear que possui o maior número de personagens, é também o mais equilibrado, possui uma excelente trilha sonora e tem diversos modos para diferenciar um pouco, sendo eles o clássico modo Arcade, um Story Mode para cada personagem do jogo, modo M.O.M, Mission, Survival e os demais que já são esperados como Training e é claro, Versus mode e Online, além de um Team Battle onde cada jogador (ou a CPU) escolhem 3 personagens para lutar (um em cada round).

A mecânica do jogo é bem complexa, cada personagem possui diversos golpes e combos que podem serem feitos, além de golpes especiais que por sua maioria são feitos com o clássico "meia lua" e Overdrivers que são golpes especiais que utilizam barra Tension, em outras palavras é a barra de especial do jogo, que também é utilizada para usar outras mecânicas como Psych Burst (um movimento especial um pouco mais forte que um especial normal, e um pouco mais fraco que um Overdrive), Cancel (cancela um ataque/combo e instantaneamente você pode voltar a começar outro ataque ou combo) e "Faultless Defense" (defesa absoluta onde o personagem não sofre dano algum). Para aprender todos as mecânicas do jogo requer que o jogador treine um pouco, com o tempo você irá se acostumar se tiver se esforçado o suficiente. Guilty Gear é um jogo que utiliza 5 botões, sendo eles K (kick), P (punch), S (slash), HS (high slash) e D (dust). Além de tudo já mencionado antes, o jogo também possui o Instant Kill para cada personagem, porém não é muito fácil de acertar o oponente e caso você use e erre, ficará sem a barra Tension até o final do round.
Quanto aos personagens, são 25 ao total, cada um com um estilo diferente e ataques próprios. Os gráficos são todos em 2D e muito bem feitos, não tanto quanto os de BlazBlue (jogo criado pela mesma empresa e também mais moderno) mas ainda assim tem seu próprio charme.

Se você gosta bastante de jogos de luta, recomendo muito a série Guilty Gear. Se você é novato na série poderá ter algumas dificuldades no inicio, mas é só treinar que com o tempo consegue pegar o jeito, para isso há o modo Training, dentro do jogo também tem uma opção "help" onde explica um pouco sobre cada mecânica da luta. Agora se você é novato em jogos de luta em geral, eu não recomendaria começar por este jogo, não é algo impossivel, mas é que Guilty Gear não é um jogo muito "fácil". Esteja bastante familiarizado com jogos de combate 2D que utilizam "meia lua" e demais mecânicas para golpes especiais e semelhantes, Guilty Gear é um jogo bastante rápido e requer... velocidade em seus movimentos.

18967571.review:
I seriously super recommend this game.

Pretty much my favouritest fighting game of all time at this point. I like this more than Bloody Roar 3, Street Fighter IV, BlazBlue, Sküllgirls, and anything else that comes to mind. All the characters are lovable, the soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, the gameplay is absolutely perfectly balanced between casual and competitive, and is just outright fun to play. It's just fun. The characters are entertaining and look good, the animations are good, and the voices are good too. They're all extremely unique, too, and as soon as I started the game up for the first time I immediately connected to them, unlike, say, Street Fighter. I have way more hours in Street Fighter, and yet I can't say I care for 90% of the characters. Ryu's okay, Sakura's cool, and I kind of like Guile, and some others... but when I opened up Guilty Gear, and went straight to the versus mode, I just looked at everyone, and said, wow, these are some awesome characters.

I pretty much picked May once, and then immediately decided she would be my main from then on. But I still can't help but like everyone else, still, they're all just really, really cool, and all feel like they have their own stories and personalities, all of which I can kind of get just by playing as them. And then there's all their story modes, which I haven't even got around to yet...

Some of my other favourite characters are Johnny, Baiken, Bridget, Sol, Ky, I-No... and then, honourable mentions to Faust and Dizzy. And then everyone else. But I guess I can say those first five are my secondary favourites, though I just kind of like Faust's hilariously weird theme, and then I just find Dizzy cute, and oddly interesting as a character. And everyone else is cool too. Just, I don't care for them quite as much obviously.

... But yeah, if you want an amazing, top tier fighting game, that you probably will never ever get to play online, because the net code is terrible, then... here you go! Grab a couple of DS3 controllers or something and you're set. Or your fightsticks, or whatever.

Also, May is the best.

17041440.review:
Muthafuckin' guilty gear. Odds are, if you're even on this store page outside of a recommendation, you've already played this ages-old game, and are looking to play it again. Do it. 

Guilty Gear is a well established fighting game series which comes to us from Arc System Works, veterans of the genre. Both their other franchise BlazBlue as well as Guilty Gear have much to offer. Characters are extremely well designed, with each one boasting their own select set of skills and moves. The best part of Guilty Gear, and the feature that sets it well apart from other fighting games, is the balance of the fighters. Nearly every game I play with friends ends up with one of us on a pixel left of health by the end of the match. This makes the fights feel EXTREMELY intense, and any game that can actually get my heart going is a game I'm interested in. Button mashing isn't enough, and you'll come to learn all sorts of new techniques and mechanics as you play. 

HIGHLY recommended for ANY fan of fighting games.

16982597.review:
Guilty Gear XX ACCENT CORE PLUS R is the latest and possibly last Revision for this nearly 15 year old Game
It is by far the most balanced Fighting Game ever with huge in-depth Mechanics and Modes. Since the Mechanics to explain can fill entire Pages, i recommend visiting the Dustloop Wiki for more Infos.

Besides the Mechanics, also the Characters and the Music (made both by Daisuke Ishiwatari) contributed to the huge success of this Series. It is easy to say that it belongs to the Top 3 of Fighting Games (Tekken, SF and GG)

Accent Core as a Revision was also completely redone with new Looks (GUI, Menus, Character Portraits, etc.) and also the Voicing of all Characters are remade. Since Core Plus there is also a new Story Mode (2 Paths for each Char except Justice, Kliff and Holy Order Sol) and the R Revision received a brand new GUI which replaced that of Accent Core.

As a Side Note, BlazBlue is also made by ARCsys (Only Music made by Daisuke) and shares some Mechanics but hasn't the same Depth.

It offers many Modes such as a Story Mode, Missions, Survival, etc.
The Story Mode is recommended to grasp the Personalities of the Characters and to see which suits you the best.

Here are some of my Pro/Contra Points:

Pro:
-Good PC Port from the Consoles
-Variety of many Characters
-Awesome Rock/Metal Music
-Voiced Story Mode
-All Stages from Slash/#Reload Revision are included (must be unlocked through Story Mode)
-Good Game Mechanics
-Network Mode! (#R has only Fanmade Network Mode)
-Latest Revision with new Moves and Balancing for all Characters

Contra:
-Slightly higher Frame Delay than the #R PC Version (5F while #R has 2F set)
-Slash/#Reload Stages can only be used Offline and not in Network Mode
-Announcer and some Voices of the Characters (for Example: Baiken has now the Voice of an old Grandma, etc.) are poorly redone. They were better in the Old pre Accent Core Revisions.
-Network Mode is suboptimal at Times (It uses Frame Delay Input and not GGPO which is faster but has also its own Flaws)
-Steep Learning Curve while progressing
-Not much Players online depending on Times. Check the "Find Player" Thread in the GGAC+R Steam Forum for Players in your Region

That's all. KEEP YOURSELF ALIVE!
Abayo...

The “startups of the special moves” are too slow…same goes to some other chars…and reverse boosting some other chars: Zappas for example knife summon got huge buff and looks overpowered sometimes… Chipp Zanuff looks ridiculously fast. Baiken’s counter hits could be a real nightmare. Millia Rage if played well is almost unstoppable…same goes to Dizzy…yep >.<  I ve played a LOT vs pros using this chars…and if they are mastered…the game is starting to look as “almost” balanced..

-(-0.25). The netcode is good. The netplay is good but a little clumsy. We all do need a lobby via XXreload style.  The delay is good but tricky sometimes…sometimes I do host and when we play I have a little delay…sometimes I don’t have any(!) delay( I have 75mbit internet).
Also looking for a ggpo online infected. Or some custom network patch like it was in ggxxreload online that was made from a scratch by a Japanese guys(yes this game has it’s own cult)
Just so I could rate this game almost 10/10!
~~
Overall don’t be scared about my last statements…the online mode is still good! Very – very playable and enjoyable. I just wish that it was perfect as the rest of the game.
And the balance is solid…just some really stupid decisions about some minor moves.
~~

Well – did you read all of this? Thanks if yes.
If not just buy this AMAZING game and read the review!
Stunning fighting game that no one even come close! 
Let’s ROCK!

ALF™.

Yeah & add me to the steam friends if  you wanna play some online guilty gear +r!

16746490.review:
While I [u]do[/u] recommend this game, I cannot recommend it to anyone who
A) does not already play fighting games
or
B) is not prepared to spend a bunch of hours learning why GGXX (and beyond) is one of the best fighters ever!

Why?
Because it offers more freedom of choice than other fighters.
How?
For instance, in most fighting games, you're (rightfully) quite screwed if you do a bad jump. In Guilty Gear you don't stop thinking at the jump. Will the jumping character attack, air-block (or air-instant block, a sort of semi-parry) any ground normals, spend meter for blocking anti-air specials, double-jump, air-dash forward/backwards? (Not counting character specific stuff as triple jumping etc.)

The character (mechanics) design is quite extreme too, since almost every character has one or more exception from the standard game mechanics, like: triple jump, double air dash, parry, delayed wakeup on sweep, not being able to dash, being able to level up specials and supers, having a heat gauge that allows for more damaging normals but also running the risk of over-heating unless venting steam (yeah, really) and more... 


Of course, my recommendation is quite biased:
I was a casual arcade game scrub since the start of the 1990s and took a liking for 2D fighting games. When I came across the console version of Guilty Gear XX #R and more importantly, people who played it seriously, GG almost became more than a game to me.

I played the game with my friends for hours on a daily basis. I went to tournaments, domestic as well as abroad. This was before there were any real prize money to speak of, meaning that VERY few (if anyone) would actually have their expenses covered. Still, I have zero regret for the time and money I have spent playing this game!

16580278.review: My favorite fighting game of all time. Fast, responsive controls, an eclectic cast of wildly diverse characters for every playstyle, amazing hand-drawn sprites and the most rockin' soundtrack you're likely to ever hear in a video game all come together to create an insane experience that is still second-to-none. The only problem is that the online for this game is dead. Guilty Gear has never been a mainstream series like Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat, so finding people to play online with is hard without arranging something ahead of time. When you do finally find someone to play with, you'll probably get crushed. The Guilty Gear scene has a small, but dedicated niche of players who are really, really good; some of them have been perfecting their skills since 2002, when the original release of XX dropped, and some even earlier than that. Not only that, but the netcode isn't exactly the best. Sometimes, you'll be fighting against the lag more than your actual opponent. There is plenty of content here for solo players to get some enjoyment, and the tried-and-true local multiplayer is still fine, but the online could use some work. Still, GGXX is a game nobody should miss out on, and AC+R is the most complete version of it.

16227713.review:
In a culumination of over a decade of revisions, insane characters, rockin' music and killer style, what sits before you is an easy contender for one of the greatest fighting games ever.

+R is the result of four immediately preceding games in the XX series, coming with 25 extremely individual and complex characters, matched only by a fighitng system which encourages the very essence of its titular character's main trait: freedom. Guilty Gear is freedom in that if you can imagine it, with practice and understanding, you can probably do it. The game allows for some of the greatest flexibility in any game, and you'll derive as much enjoyment from discovering its nuances as you will beating opponents senseless and rocking out doing so.

This is the game that got me playing fighting games, made me appreciate game design, and made me appreciate Queen. Without question, this is a game for the ages. Buy it.

【罪恶回忆录】
大概是十年前的一天，我从同学那里借了一本游戏杂志。
偶然间翻到一页，介绍一款格斗游戏的角色攻略打法。
当时眼中看到的两个游戏角色让我虎躯一震！
这是什么格斗游戏？游戏人物也太TM奇葩了吧！
（当时就记住了FA的蹲姿纸袋头和PO庞大的身躯）
那个玩的同学告诉我：罪恶装备，最华丽的格斗游戏！
然后就开始跟我讲“我在PS2上玩了，贼**爽！高手过招，
粘着就完”。。。虽然我听得是云里雾里的，
但是当时我喜欢玩街机模拟器上的格斗游戏，
于是就记住了这个游戏——《罪恶装备》
后来这个游戏陪伴了我快十年的时光，从高中到结婚！
由于这是一篇用户测评而不是回忆录，我还是就此打住吧。。。

【加强版测评】（2015年12月12日 最后の更新？）

*简评前作*
《Guilty Gear XX #Reload -The Midnight Carnival》
初玩PC上的#R。第一感受就是GG有着另类独特的游戏角色，
张狂喧哗的对战风格。之后我感受到的是复杂严谨的游戏系统，
望而生畏的入门难度。直到现在。爽快激烈的立回对攻，
手段丰富的压制多择，酣畅淋漓的连段打击，
紧张刺激的心里博弈，让GG陪伴了我十年。
而玩了一段时间ACPR之后...
对不起我几句话没法表达清楚，请童鞋们往下看...

*入正与否*
本作《GUILTY GEAR XX ACCENT CORE PLUS R》
登陆Steam着实让我喜出望外，于是果断入正收藏了。
我想和我有一样情感的玩家也入正了吧。还在观望的PC玩家，
我应该是在犹豫入正后能否有良好的联机对战体验。

——【重点】——以下是15年12月12日更新的几句测评。
本作发售至今已有半年时间，就我所知的玩家反映。
联机对战体验一直未得到改善，个人与好友联机新出的Xrd，
也发现并非网络问题，而是游戏自身联机环境没有优化！
个人推测将来官方也不会推出优化联机的更新补丁。
假如以满分10分为总分，完全出于个人感情，我给本作打9分。
但是，对于正版FTG的核心要素——网战体验来打分，5分！

我建立了一个ACPR的网战交流组，目前有100+多人：
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ggacn
由于不是Q群，大家都不是很活跃。
加了几个好友能够流畅的网战的确实有几人。
抛开网战和收藏，只是闲暇时间打打CPU随便玩玩的话，嗯...
（PS:假如大家去玩破解版记得去游侠下载升级补丁！
解决了PC版许多bug和问题！）

*上手体验*
GG系列是公认的门槛高入门难，
而当对面的CPU轻松的使用了FRC连段和SB防御时候...
我再次开始怀疑人生！不得不感叹GG这座大山越来越高了。
本来我就手残，肛playFRC成功率不到50%，
键盘打6246这样的觉醒更是折磨。
但是我无意间看到了出招表中的FB必杀？什么鬼？
啊哦！消耗25%TG的必杀技嘛！赶紧在练习模式用Sol试一试！
GC接426D和J26D，这尼玛Duang的根本停不下来！
妈妈再也不用担心我因为放不出FRC而白白浪费TG槽了！
这FB必杀真是初级玩家的福音！ACPR的门槛比#R又高了不少，
但是上手难度却降低了很多！这点让我喜出望外！
像我这种初级打电脑玩家的话，在立回和连段中能用到TG的快感，
你们不懂。本作的上手体验，真是无与伦比的爽快啊！
虽然GG这座山越来越高，
但是这次我们可以不必感叹那遥不可及的顶峰。
因为山下有着同样美丽的景色！

*进阶测评*（游戏时间100+小时的更新测评）
100小时后我又回去玩了玩最开始的#R和后来玩的BBCSEX。
这十年间偶尔也试了试十几款其他的PC格斗游戏。
现在再来说一说ACPR的体验。

操作手感：
ACPR相较于#R，新的必杀、FB必杀让每个机体都有了新的提高！
机师的操作空间变大了很多！拆投、贴壁、滑地、LOOP、SB防御
更爽快！更流畅！ACPR比#R好玩多了！没sei了！！！
GC上手连段接必杀FB、GC连携压制、FD拉距离、空DASH
对初接触FTG的玩家来说，很快就能感受到对战的多变性！
而且各角色操控系统都有不小的差距。。。
各种 花式起攻择、稳压关厕所、猜招近身凹、中屏摸到死、
扑街指令投、父子二打一、开火车、电疗、潮汐、爆菊、防反、
陷阱、打防、弹幕、凭依、悠悠球、座充、嗑药、一击必杀
（刚接触GG的玩家先玩 Sol Ky Faust 纱梦 Kliff 上手）

画面声音：（都是些细节）
角色被砍中后的光效从“喷血+白色割裂光线”变成了
“更粗更明显的白色光线”（取消了喷血。。。）
FD防御光效变更，增加了防御特殊技砍击的光效。
必杀技击中后的画面彩色线条效果微变更。
武器砍中的音效也有细微改变。个人觉得#R的打击音效很糟。
本作武器砍人的音效稍微比#R强一点点。。。
增加了角色在水中走跑的声音，比如HELL这张图，
同时有水和地面，人物从水中跑到陆上跑步声会有变化。
一句话概括就是本作比#R加了更多的特技进去。。。

16108331.review:
This is a good port of a superb arcade fighting game. Unlike its release on PS3, the PC version can be made compatible with 4:3 screens like CRTs, which is important because it is a native 480p game. In that respect the PS3 version was actually a downgrade from the previous PS2 title, Accent Core Plus, because it scaled everything up to 720p and forced you to use sidebars of some kind.

I would definitely recommend this over any of the console ports. The PC is compatible with more arcade sticks than any other platform, and you can run the game with any kind of display, which makes streaming and recording a breeze.

Keep in mind that this is a much more difficult game to master than BlazBlue or the newer Guilty Gear, Xrd. There are certain moves that require precision on the order of two or three frames, which is a very small interval at 60FPS. The era of internet play, wireless controllers, and laggy LCDTVs has made GGXXAC+R less relevant in the mainstream, but for shoulder-to-shoulder play, it simply cannot be beat.

16076562.review:
Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus R is the latest of the XX series and the most balanced game of the franchise right now. For those who are not familiar: Guilty Gear is a heavily combo-based fighting game. It's fast-paced and requires a lot of skill to get good.

The port is very well done and Arc System Works (the developer) is always providing bugfixes and making improvements on this PC version. With 25 characters to choose from and a lot of game modes to keep you occupied and challenge you (offline and online), Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus R is worth the money if you're into fighting games.

PROS:

+ 25 very different characters. There's no Ryu / Ken here. Each one is unique
+ CPU is very good at reading your moves and one of the best I've ever seen
+ Soundtrack is phenomenal. You'll certainly rise the BGM volume in-game
+ Great story and easy to understand, even if you never played any GG game
+ Online is good, unless you're playing with someone very very far away from you
+ Skill-heavy gameplay. You're always on the edge of your seat
+ Works with different types of controllers and arcade sticks

MIXED:

> There's no tutorial, making it harder to start if you're not familiar with fighting games
> Arcade mode boss is very cheap. This can be good or bad. Depends on you

CONS:

-  There's no combo practice mode. I like to create my own combos, but some suggestions from the devs would be welcome

---

Bottom line: If you're a fan of fighting games, this is a no-brainer + you'll have a lot of fun! If you're starting on the genre, I would recommend Street Fighter (any of them, because of the easier inputs), Skullgirls (great tutorial to introduce you to fighting games in general) or BlazBlue Continuum Shift Extend / Chrono Phantasma (good tutorial and combo practice mode).
