16066384.review:
"Give in to your guilty pleasures and start fighting for Heaven or Hell in the best version of Guilty Gear X2."
Guilty Gear X2 Accent Core Plus is the definitive version of all things Guilty Gear X2 related. And trust me; there is plenty of stuff related to GGX2. For the record, I don't count Guilty Gear Isuka as part of the Guilty Gear X2 re-releases. I don't care how many A.B.A. fans I upset when I say that, either. After Guilty Gear X2's initial release, fighting game fans got hit with plenty of remakes of Arc System's crazy chaos combat contest. Thus, you might be wondering if you should bother picking up this game. Well, yes, you should. Look at it this way: do you want the most up to date character roster, the most balanced move set, the most information regarding the Guilty Gear mythos and the most modes alongside the classic arcade and versus? Of course you do! Anyone can see that GGX2ACP is the game to get for those who want the most out of the world of Guilty Gear. Trust me when I say that there is plenty of “most” for everyone.

Those new to Guilty Gear might be a bit lost in terms of story. The cast of Guilty Gear is eccentric and wild; the types of people you want to hang around with at a party. Due to the aggressive and dangerous nature of Gears, bounty hunters and The Sacred Order of the Holy Knights alike waged a century long war to end the existence of all Gears. Tournaments have been held in the past to extinguish any remaining Gears and the ruler of all Gears: Justice. In doing so, the victors are granted money. Lots and lots money. That's the basic premise behind the Guilty Gear world, but the characters and their eccentricities are what make the game so special. There are no Ryu/Ken types here, thankfully. Instead, you have a huge cast you'd never expect to find. There is Bridgette, a transvestite who fights with yo-yos, stuffed animal and roller blades. There is also Slayer, a vampire with more power than a generator that controls a continent. Seriously, he blocks attacks with smoke from his pipe! We also have the beautiful Millia Rage, an assassin trained to use her gorgeous hair as a weapon. All of your favorites are back and one of the draws of Guilty Gear Accent Core Plus is the fact that two fan favorite characters have joined the roster: Kliff and Justice. While these overpowered jerks are rarely used in normal play or in tournaments, it's still great to see familiar faces and have such a huge variety of characters. With the up to date story mode, you can find out more about each unique character as they battle the entities known as Gears and the mysterious figure known only as “That Man.” All characters have multiple endings in their story modes. Since each arc is short, you can see different sides of the tale.

Alongside Story Mode, there is a new Survival Mode that allows you to level up your characters as you battle the computer. You can also play the regular Arcade, Training, Versus, M.O.M, Versus Computer and Two-vs.-Two Modes. Accent Core Plus will let you go on-line provided you have the proper PS2 attachments. Once a mode is picked, you select a character and once a character is picked, the fun begins again. The fighting is as hectic as ever yet still retains the familiarity of all of the predecessors. Characters have a variety of attacks, skills and the potential to chain them all together to create impressive combos that demand respect. All characters have strengths and weaknesses, but knowing how each character performs will lead to huge combos and a better understanding of how to battle other opponents. As usual, there is plenty to offer in Accent Core Plus in terms of strategy that goes beyond a standard combo. Techniques such as Faultless Defense, Roman Cancelling, False Roman Cancelling (more on those in a minute) and others are needed to fully get the most out of the fighting. All in all, fighting is a blast. The computer controlled AI does not pull any punches even on the easier difficulty settings. Practice makes perfect when it comes to picking a character that's right for you. This leads me to my biggest complaint about the game: the lack of a good practice mode. Sure, Training Mode gives you some options but it would have been nice to include a mode that gives you hints about the basics of 2D fighting, combo ideas and strategies. Considering this is the best version of Guilty Gear X2, an extra mode would have helped to sell the package and set it apart from the other releases. One of the good things that the Training Mode offers is that it allows you to learn the input of executing a False Roman Cancel. False Roman Cancels, or FRCs, allow you to stop most attacks mid-animation and either follow up with an impressive combo or dash away in case an attack missed. They're very important, but also very trick to learn. Since all characters have different FRCs, learning the timing for each of them will take effort. However, this effort is worth it and it was a good move on Arc's part to include the FRC practice feature.

Despite the lack of a more involved Training Mode, there are some great things to point out that you can only find in Accent Core Plus: bonus material. As you complete the various challenges, you'll unlock stunning artwork. Fans know that the illustrations in Guilty Gear have always been amazing and what better way to see them than as a reward for winning a tough match? Get ready to see the Game Over screen and hit the start button while a countdown begins. Luckily, the rewards for your troubles are well worth it. Once again, anime is the central theme in the graphics department. Animations and scenery look like they should: excellent and full of vivid details. The rock and roll inspired soundtrack is back in full swing, as well. For those of you that buy the game new, you will get the OST on a separate disc so you can rock out with your...well...you know....when not playing Guilty Gear. Finally, all of the voice acting is in Japanese.

The best thing about Guilty Gear X2 Accent Core Plus is that it has everything a fan of the series could want with just enough extra stuff to set it apart from other remakes of X2. To me, the best part is the free soundtrack. However, even without it, this is still an excellent 2D fighting game from a legendary franchise. All of the characters and their crazy moves, the gorgeous graphics, the awesome music and the endless amount of options available to you make this game one worth checking out. Having now fully immersed myself in both BlazBlue and Guilty Gear, I can easily say that Guilty Gear is the better of the two. Both series are great, but there is something about Guilty Gear that sets it just above its counterpart. If that's not going to convince you to purchase Guilty Gear X2 Accent Core Plus, then nothing will.


Reviewer's Score: 9/10

As a Guilty Gear Fan this was pretty much an immediate buy. Thanks Steam!

The good
-----
-Large cast of characters that are quite diverse in terms of what they do and what their backstory is. A rule of thumb, the farther from the center of the character selection screen the character is, the more complicated that character is going to play. You'll sure to have a unique experience with many of the characters in the game. 
-The game goes through constant rebalancing as the devs know this is a game that players like to compete in.
-Awesome soundtrack and art design. 
-There is much to do in terms of unlocking. Each character has an alternate EX version that plays in a "similar but different" form of the original. 

The Bad
-----
-Limited graphic settings. The game is locked to 4:3 (understandable, the original was in 4:3 back in the last decade). If you play in full screen, the only way to exit the game seems to be ALT-F4 at the moment. Thankfully, the game runs fine in 144hz, unlike some other 2d fighters released on steam.

The Ugly
----
Having to reunlock the EX versions of the characters yet again if you played earlier console versions (All of the original roster is unlocked from the get-go, including Justice and Kliff). Here's hoping someone finds a way to re unlock the EX characters asap. :P

OK, let's get things clear out of the way. If you want to buy this game solely for online mode, forget about it. It's not that GGXXAC+R's netcode is bad or anything (it's actually quite decent). Fighting games are meant to be played with friends, face-to-face. It's way more fun to play with a bunch of guys, sitting behind the screen, cheering for the underdog,screaming when something dope happen etc you know what I mean. Plus, network delay is one of the main reason I dont bother with playing online anymore. It just doesnt feel right at all when you're used to playing with delay-free situation (this is what gamer usually aim for regardless of what game they play). However. spending a bit of time with online mode isnt so bad. But still, I'm not recommend playing on online mode.

So, if you're not buying this game because of the online mode, why should you buy it then? Well, for starter, It's GUILTY GEAR ffs, the game  that havent released a new version on PC for like 10 years. New story to be discovered. Believe me when I say this, but GGXXAC+R's story is absolutely awesome (yeah, I kinda went through the whole story mode when there was a GGXXAC PS2 rom on PCSX2)

What's more to add? Arcade mode's got enhanced with the addition to the hidden Order-Sol Boss (that bastard is really hard to chew), Boss I-no's got a quite few tweak herself with the addition of disabling Instant Kill, making it more challenging

Survival mode is quite cool as well, you have to ability to power-up your character after defeating each boss. Still. no save function. But hey, it's survival mode. Why do you even need a save function for?

Saving the best for last, we have the major gameplay update. More balance than the previous versions, more mechanics to vastly improve the "every-situation-has-an-answer" property, namely throw break, slashback (this one is quite hard to use effectively though). Then we have 2 new characters (A.B.A and Order-Sol) and 2 re-balanced character that was consider OP and was ban from every Tournament (yes, I'm talking about Kliff and Justice)

TL;DR: 10/10 would buy for the game's content

The current pinnacle of the Guilty Gear series finally arrives on Steam and in a fairly well port. Easily the most well-balanced entry of the series and sports the largest cast as well coming in at 25 combatants. For gameplay modes it sports Arcade, story, vs, team vs, mission, survival, training, & online. There is also a gallery in which you can view at atwork and other content you have unlock while playing.

The online play is touchy subject of this title as it can be really good or really bad entirely based on the distance from other players. For example the online feels next to perfect playing against my friend who lives about 40 minutes away by car but playing random people online, it can show some seriously bad input lag. It should also be noted there is no spectating or lobbies for that matter if that was something which interested you.

As for the port, it runs a lot smoother than the steam store page would lead you to expect with the high recommend specs, so much so i'd guess the real recommended specs are much lower. The only serious port issue i've encountered at this time is no way in-game to exit the game, but that is said to be on a 'To-Do' list. Its also nice that they throw in the OST for the game as an added bonus (though it should be noted certain shared tracks in the game itself are in the included Guilty Gear XX #Reload OST instead of this one, so view this more like an OST expansion).

I really recommend this game as the ideal starting point if you want to get into Guilty Gear, though it should be noted Guilty Gear does have a learning curve, so don't expect good results running up blind against a seasoned player. At $14.99, you will get your money's worth on content.

16029830.review:
This review is from the standpoint of a competitive player already familiar with the game, intended for those who are also familiar with the game, but unsure about the quality of the port.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list][*]Offline gameplay is smooth and runs at full-speed easily.
[*]Mechanically identical to the most recent arcade and console releases.
[*]AC+R mode is toggled on by default. If you want to go back in time, switch to AC mode in the Game Options menu.
[*]Adds arcade-only sidebars!
[*]Dev team seems committed, some issues already patched out in the first 24 hours.
[*]Self-published, adds a glimmer of hope for future releases.
[*]Controllers and arcade sticks recognized by default, and full keyboard bindings are available as well as a separate menu.
[*]Netplay allows inviting via Steam friends list.[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list][*]Connections always read as 4-bars, and delay is significant across the board. Connections that were acceptable on PS3 are slower here. (Upside: connections are significantly smoother, no bursts of delay. Hopefully the standard delay is fixable.)
[*]Not much in the way of resolution support, and playing in fullscreen has issues. (If your monitor is >60Hz, the game will read 60fps but run faster. Fullscreen also seems to add additional input delay.)
[*]Windowed by default, and resolution options are limited. (Default is 1280x720, native res, good enough imo.)
[*]Game reads controllers, but assigns buttons incorrectly - though prompts will read "B" to cancel, you need to press "X", for example.
[*]Windows decides who is Player 1 and who is Player 2 - the game does not ask you to select a side when you start. This also leads to issues like Windows treating you as Player 2, forcing you to bind keys for that side, while netplay only uses Player 1's binds. Only a serious issue re: netplay, since every offline mode works fine as 2P.
[*]Tabbing back into the game if it wasn't on top causes brief (1-2s) slowdown.[/list]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[b]It's AC+R on PC.[/b] As things stand now, it's only good for offline play, but netplay stands a decent chance of getting fixed. Keep your expectations realistic (we won't be seeing GGPO, for example) and it's absolutely worth a purchase.

16029433.review:
As far as fast paced anime styled fighting games are concerned, this is the definitive one. However, since it's a port, certain issues must be accounted for.

The good:
+ 24 characters - more than enough to find one you like
+ Each character is enormously unique - no two play alike once you start to understand how to play them properly
+ Most polished and advanced battle system - the potential to explore the game is nigh infinite
+ Hours of single player content - RPG like Survival mode, Score attack (M.O.M.), challenge mode (Numerous unique missions, matches played under very specific circumstances), branching Story Mode (visual novel style)

The bad:
- Netcode is 1:1 as it was on consoles, IT MUST BE UPDATED. It's possible to play and play effectively, but mostly you will not be so lucky. Only play with friends until patches arrive.


Other than that there are reports of small bugs, but at the same time patches/fixes are already going live. There's no reason not to buy GGXXAC+R as it is now.

전작에 비해 뭔가 바뀐거 같긴 한데...사실 크게 바뀐게 없는거 같다. 탠션을 조금 쓰는 스킬이 추가된 정도?

전작을 해보지 않은 분들을 위해 설명하자면, 간단한 "평타+콤보or필살기" 정도는 상당히 쉬운 게임이지만, 깊게 파고들면 파고들수록 프레임 단위의 타이밍으로 포스로망캔슬같은 괴랄한 기술을 익혀야만 제대로 콤보를 쓸수 있는 매니악한 격투게임이다. 간단히 놀기도 좋고, 무겁게 놀기도 좋은 격투게임. 게다가 스토리모드는 격투게임의 스토리를 알아가는 재미를 준다.(문제는 떡밥만 실컷 던지고 끝낸다는 거지만)
문제는 이러한 격투게임이 길티기어만 존재하느냐 하면, 사실 킹오파13이 훨씬 그쪽에 가까운 편이고, 길티기어의 형제 격이라고 할 수 있는 블레이블루 또한 그러하다. 오히려 킹오파13이나 블레이블루 CS의 경우는 생초보를 위한 튜토리얼과 콤보연습 기능까지 있기에 접근성에 있어서 길티기어보다 훨씬 좋다.
혹자는 "오래된 게임을 이식한 것이기에 큰 기대는 안하는 것이 좋다"고 할 수 있는데, 그 말이 맞다. 이 게임은 사실 오래된 게임이며, 길티기어의 팬들을 위해 pc판으로 즐길 수 있도록 배려한 것이다. 그렇기에 사실 난 길티기어를 전혀 모르는 사람들에게 이 게임을 추천하기가 망설여진다는 것이다. 지금 현재 이보다 훨씬 세련되고 화려한 게임은 상당히 많은데 굳이 이 게임을 해야 할 이유를 설명할 수 없는 것이다.

하지만 이 게임이 킹오파나 블레이블루에 비해 압도적으로 유리한 장점이 있었으니, 바로 가격! 다른 메이저 격투게임에 비해 2~3배는 싼 가격이다. 게다가 특전으로 주는 사운드트랙은 정말 최고다.

"다른 격겜에 비해 압도적으로 저렴한 가격+최고의 사운드 트랙" 이 정도면 확실히 추천할 만 하지 않을까?

16022059.review:
I have done this little review for general consumer, I prefer compare this game whit RELOAD 
because ISUKA was an spinoff and is not part of the official cannon and use different 
mechanics.
 

PROS:

- a solid and rewarding Fighting game, it is difficult to learn (or stop to be a button smasher) and much more difficult to be a good or a competitive player.
- Huge and colorful 2D hand-draw Sprites and maps
- includes a good IA., in maniac mode it can be a challenge. 
- It includes all reglamentary game modes (ARCADE, VS CPU, SURVIVAL, VS PLAYER, PRACTICE, ONLINE) and extra ones (M.O.M, TEAM VS CPU, TEAM VS PLAYER, Story, Mission )

CONS:

- you can't stretch the game to fit your Screen. in other words you will have two border despite resolution or mode you choose (windowed or full)
- the netcode is not for slow connections, if you have a crappy connection below to 8mb, forget it. 


IMPROVEMENTS SINCE RELOAD:

- a completely new Story mode follows the events of RELOAD.
- now you can choose the map or the music you want to fight (simply but is a nice touch)
- 2 NEW characters were added, A.B.A. from Guilty Gear Isuka and Order SOl from Guity Gear Slash (consoles and arcade JAPAN only)
- Cliff and Justice were re-added on RELOAD (Unlockebles) but their mechanics has been improved to be use in tournaments (AKA. they are not overpower anymore)
- all arworks and voice-overs for all characters have been redone 
- you can choose between 2 different voice acting for SOL and ORDER SOL, Daisuke Ishiwatari (it's creator) and Jouji Nakata (George)
- a new announcer (it depends of your tastes he can like you or annoy you)
- all the maps has been improved and they added it's alternative versions from isuka, maps like FRASCO or CHINA looks really good.
- you can unlock exclusive illustrations for the gallery or if you clear the story mode you can unlock secret voice actor interviews

this is a new game for PC gamers, we stuck on RELOD since 2006, now we can enjoy now of our new candy!

16021110.review:
Introdução:

Guilty Gear é uma série de jogos de luta da empresa Arc System Works. Este jogo é a revisão final (e provavalmente definitiva) da saga "XX" de Guilty Gear.

Houveram três Guilty Gears entre o XX # Reloaded e o Accent Core + R, nenhum destes disponiveis infelizmente na Steam: Slash que portou a novata A.B.A de I s u k a além de um nova versão de Sol Badguy no seu tempo da "Holy Order", além que diversos personagens ganharam novos golpes, além de claro um rebalanceamento.

Accent Core finalmente mudou os artworks e narrador que estavam sendo usados desde Guilty Gear XX original (isso são quatro jogos!), também com novos cenários e dublagens (alguns se aposentaram ou trocaram de ramo, como a dubladora do Bridget, Hiroko Konishi). Porém por alguns bugs de "travamento" foi feito logo depois exclusivo para os consoles o "Accent Core+", que também trazia um novo story mode, missões e retorno de Kliff e Justice que tinham sido cortados no AC original (ainda sim eles eram banidos para campeonatos).

Então finalmente em Setembro de 2012 foi lançado Guilty Gear Accent Core + R para a placa arcade RingEdge 2 da Sega. Além de "novamente" mais uma revisão do jogo finalmente Kliff e Justice foram adaptados em versões competitivas, antes disso Accent Core tinha sido portado no final de 2012 para PSN e XBLA, Arc System Works então portou o upgrade de graça de 2013 em diante. Está é a versão disponível na STEAM.

Conteudo:

Acredito que muitos pularam de Guilty Gear XX # Reloaded para este jogo se somente seguiram a série pelo PC, os novos personagens então são:

A.B.A - Uma personagem com 2 modos: um com mobilidade limitada e outra por tempo limitado com muito mais versátilidade porém com perigo ao acabar o modo. Ela luta junto de seu "amigo" chave Paracelcus
Order Sol - Sol Badguy mais "jovem", com as vestes da "Holy Order" seu estilo de luta é menos "lapidado" como a versão atual, além que conta com um novo gameplay baseado em golpes "melhorados" provenientes do uso de uma segunda barra de "Charge".
Kliff Undersn - O comandante chefe da "Holy Order", seu gameplay foi adptado para "stunar" seu inimigo com seus golpes, porém há um risco de usando ele errado o jogador acabar com Kliff "stunado"
Justice - A "chefona" do primeiro Guilty Gear, o "primeiro" Gear, retorna com grande parte de suas opções de movimentação cortada (sem nenhum tipo de dash e apenas pulo duplo), seu gameplay consiste em "zonear" seu oponente para conseguir "tension" e assim finalmente partir pra cima, ainda sim é um personagem que requer bastante paciência.

O game contém diversos modos: Story, Arcade, M.O.M, Survival, Training, Team VS...bastante coisa para se distrair estando sozinho com o jogo. O modo de história não tem cutscenes, animações ou musicas durante os diálogos como os da série BlazBlue mas cumprem seu trabalho de dar mais personalidade aos lutadores do game.

Modo online infelizmente é um retrocesso em relação a BlazBlue Continuum Shift Extend. Não há como olhar uma partida online, não há lobbies (somente salas 1 vs 1) e o netplay é basedo em "delay" em um jogo que há recursos como o de "encurtar" golpes que só podem ser feitos em um tempo bem especifico. O netcode é o mesmo da versão console, teria sido ótimo se Arc System Works tivesse ido um pouco além e melhorado para a versão PC, infelizmente isso não aconteceu.

Se você joga descompromissado e tem amigos próximos para jogar online, o game cumpre o papel. Caso queira partidas sérias e que tu sabe que seu comando vai sair como quer nas partidas, infelizmente as chances são grandes de se decepcionar jogando online o game.

Não há muito conteudo novo ou exclusivo da versão STEAM. Ela contém uma opção extra do arcade de artwork lateral dinâmico usando as artes dos personagens de Accent Core +, nos consoles único do tipo é um com versoes "chibi" dos personagens. O game nas opções pelo visto também conta com a antiga versão Accent Core, porém não testei a mesma.

Controle:

O input do game foi adaptado para teclados e arcade "hitbox" segundo um dos desenvolvedores, além de claro o básico de poder reconfigurar os botões de teclado.

Na questão de controle eles simplesmente fizeram o trabalho mais fácil: apenas suporte bom para pads e arcades que suportem "X Input", então sim é preciso o uso de "xboxce" para que certos controles e arcades funcionem no jogo.

Palavras Finais:

Vale a pena? Se o foco não for jogar online sério, Guilty Gear Accent Core + R é um ótimo jogo da série. Muitos modos, personagens e é bem garantido ser a "versão suprema" do ultimo Guilty Gear "2D puro", do contrário é melhor esperar um desconto (apesar de finalmente ser um jogo da ASW com preço localizado para nós brasileiros) ou uma chance que algum fã desenvolva um netplay por fora como aconteceu com Melty Blood Current Code.

Compre também se quer incentivar novos ports da ASW na STEAM pois é o primeiro game em que Arc System Works é publisher na plataforma. Espero que faça a escolha certa.

16020993.review:
Gracious and glorious, most refined Guilty Gear.

Game itself is amazing, and is the most complete Guilty Gear to date. Lots of content both offline and online. Dev's showed a lot of love to this game, and responded to our concerns even before the release.

As for the port:

16020375.review:
Finally this game comes out for steam.  

I don't know how many times i dipped my chips to this game... But still got it, since its a really good fighting game...

This is the lastest version of GGXXAC series, but not GGXRD. Though its usually good news when more Japanese publishers pour games into steam!

The steam version though is pretty much like playing on PSN, 4:3 format with the 2 bars on both sides of the screen.
Not much on graphical changes since this game was on PS2 but the GGXXAC+R has its changes from the last update.  It does change the game quite a bit.  Brings back good memories at the arcade. SP plays just fine, MP is a lagfest but didn't expect MP to be great anyway (My expectation from PSN for MP wasn't great to begin with). Hopefully games like GGXRD will fix that... right???

Any way, I'd recommend this game for hard core fighting game fans and if you like Blazblue series, you'll like this diverse game.

If you're into SF Series, give it a try, it may surprise you.  A friendly reminder, all the characters are different.  Watch out for the yoyo guy.  Yep i said it.
